evidence.dc:description: Absence of protein expression in PBMCs and EBV-transformed B cell lines from patients in immunoblot assays.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Identification of the molecular etiologies of primary immunodeficiencies has led to important insights into the development and function of the immune system. We report here the cause of combined immunodeficiency in 4 patients from 2 different consanguineous Qatari families with similar clinical and immunologic phenotypes. The patients presented at an early age with fungal, viral, and bacterial infections and hypogammaglobulinemia. Although their B- and T-cell numbers were normal, they had low regulatory T-cell and NK-cell numbers. Moreover, patients' T cells were mostly CD45RA(+)-naive cells and were defective in activation after T-cell receptor stimulation. All patients contained the same homozygous nonsense mutation in IKBKB (R286X), revealed by whole-exome sequencing with undetectable IKKβ and severely decreased NEMO proteins. Mutant IKKβ(R286X) was unable to complex with IKKα/NEMO. Immortalized patient B cells displayed impaired IκBα phosphorylation and NFκB nuclear translocation. These data indicate that mutated IKBKB is the likely cause of immunodeficiency in these 4 patients.
dc:source.dc:creator: Mousallem T
dc:source.dc:title: A nonsense mutation in IKBKB causes combined immunodeficiency.

evidence.rdfs:label: Immunoblotting assay

evidence.dc:description: EBV-transformed B cell lines from patient, and sibling. Patient cells transfected with wild type protein or empty vector and subsequently stimulated with PMA for 10 and 20 minutes. Patient cells with WT protein express IKKB protein whereas the ones with empty vector do not show any IKKB expressed in the cytosol. NfkB expression in the nucleus increased with stimulation when WT gene is present. (Fig1I). Decreased expansion of patient-derived B cells can be corrected by full-length but not mutant IKKB (Fig 1J).
evidence.rdfs:label: IKKB signalling pathway

evidence.dc:description: Normal levels of NF-κB activation by TNF-α were restored in cells from the patient that re-expressed IKK2. This happened despite the low levels of IKK2 observed in the Western Blot.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) comprises a heterogeneous group of heritable deficiencies of humoral and cell-mediated immunity. Many patients with SCID have lymphocyte-activation defects that remain uncharacterized.
dc:source.dc:creator: Pannicke U
dc:source.dc:title: Deficiency of innate and acquired immunity caused by an IKBKB mutation.

evidence.rdfs:label: Rescue

evidence.detectionMethod: 172 very rare variants were observed and of those 5 were homozygous. Other than the IKBKB mutation (Y107X), no mutations were observed in IKBA , NEMO or other proteins if the Nf-bB pathway. NEMO was studied by sanger sequencing as it was poorly covered by the Exome data. IKBKB mutation was also confirmed by sanger sequencing and showed that both parents were heterozygous.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Normal proportions and numbers of naive and memory T, B, and natural killer cells, normal T-cell repertoire, and T-cell proliferation to PHA (Table I). Expression of MHC class II molecules was preserved. Neutrophil number was normal, as was monocytes and dendritic cell populations. Normal liver test results. 
Immunoglobulin levels at 3 months old: IgG 1.2 g/L, IgA <0.05 g/L, IgM <0.05 g/L. Absent production of IL-17 and markedly reduced production of TNF-alpha and IL-6 in response to a range of Toll-like receptors ligands (Fig1C).
Progressive respiratory distress. Died at the age of 25 months.

dc:source.dc:creator: Burns SO
dc:source.dc:title: Immunodeficiency and disseminated mycobacterial infection associated with homozygous nonsense mutation of IKKβ.

evidence.rdfs:label: Proband Burns

evidence.dc:description: Purified proteins from PBMCs from the patient demonstrated complete lack of IKBKB expression (Fig1E) using anti-IKBKB generated against peptide comprising of Leu570 and surrounding residues. No patient derived cell lines were available.
Mutation identical by descent

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Normal numbers of T an B cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 2

evidence.dc:description: Functional data already added to Family 1 so not scoring here.
Identical by descent.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Low than reference T and B cell numbers and very low NK cell numbers.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 4

evidence.dc:description: Functional data added with Family 1 so not scored here.
Homozygous mutation, probably founder mutation.

evidence.detectionMethod: Trio-based whole-exome sequencing. Only homozygous mutations in the child and heterozygous in the patient were considered. Common variants and synonymous variants were filtered out. 1 nonsense and 26 missense mutations were found. The most promising candidate was a nonsense mutation in IKBKB (R272X) within a large 50Mb region of homozygosity. Mutation confirmed by Sanger sequencing (Fig1a).
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
IgM 0.59 g/l, IgA and IgG undetectable. Normal lymphocyte subsets except for the complete absence of isotype-switched memory B cells and low numbers of CD45R0+ memory T cells. Normal dentition and only lower cuspids were conical. 
Progressive signs of systemic/ multiple site infection at the age of 9 months with intermittent fever, a nodular rash with subcutaneous infiltrations, knee arthritis, low level ascites and progressive wall thickening in the small and large intestines. Mycobacterium bovis were isolated from multiple sites.
Patient died at 14 months.

dc:source.dc:abstract: We report an infant of consanguineous parents of Turkish decent with a novel immunodeficiency associated with homozygosity for a nonsense mutation of the gene encoding Inhibitor of nuclear factor kappa-B (NF-κB) kinase subunit beta (IKKβ). At five months, she presented with respiratory insufficiency and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia which was successfully treated. At nine months, iatrogenic systemic infection with Mycobacterium bovis was found and eventually led to her death at age 14 months. Laboratory findings were reminiscent of hyper-IgM syndrome, but genetic testing gave no explanation before whole exome sequencing revealed a novel mutation abrogating signaling through the canonical NF-κB pathway.
dc:source.dc:creator: Nielsen C
dc:source.dc:title: Immunodeficiency associated with a nonsense mutation of IKBKB.

evidence.rdfs:label: Proband Nielsen

evidence.dc:description: In Western Blots of PBMCs, IKKB was completely absent from patient's blood (IKKA and NEMO were present at normal levels) (Fig1b).  Stimulation of T-cells before IL-2 therapy by anti-CD3/CD28 completely failed to phosphorylate p65 and phosphorylation was only partial after activation by PMA and Ionomycin (Fig2). T cells (gated as CD4+ or CD8+ lymphocytes) failed to proliferate in response to anti-CD3/CD28. However, proliferation was normal after after addition of IL-2 and partial proliferative responses were seen to the T-cell mitogen PHA.
Identical by descent.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Normal T an B cell numbers but low NK cell numbers. Normal response to mitogens PHA and ConA. Low IgM but detectable IgG, probably of maternal origin.
Cerebrospinal fluid revealed Listeria monocytogenes that lead to sepsis and death.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 2

evidence.dc:description: Supporting functional data described for Patient 1 so not scoring it here.
Reduced score because patient is homozygous for the same mutation and probably founder mutation with the other families.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Normal B and T cell numbers, low numbers of NK cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 3

evidence.dc:description: Functional data shown with family 1.
Homozygous mutation, probably founder mutation same as family 1 and 2.

evidence.detectionMethod: Autozygosity mapping was done in all available family members and whole genome sequencing of index member (V:5). Sanger sequencing confirmed segregation with the disease.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Early onset (2-4 months) of severe infections caused by virus, bacteria, mycobacteria and fungi.

dc:source.dc:creator: Alsum Z
dc:source.dc:title: Multiple Family Members With Delayed Cord Separtion and Combined Immunodeficiency With Novel Mutation in

evidence.rdfs:label: V:5

evidence.dc:description: Identical by descent mutation.

evidence.detectionMethod: Homozygosity mapping to confirm founder mutation was done in all four patients of the study and three healthy siblings. I was done on the Affymetrix GeneChip platform using the Genome-Wide Human SNP Array 6.0, containing 906,600 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). Only one candidate region was found that spanning a 11.6Mb region in chromosome 8 containing about 40 genes. All 40 genes were sequenced using DNA or cDNA. Only one biallelic mutation was found in all 4 patients.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Normal number of T cells, B cells and NK cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1

evidence.dc:description:
Fig 1E - Western blot analysis of primary fibroblast–derived protein from Patient 1, which had 
a complete lack of the IKK2 protein. Amounts of IκB kinase 1 (IKK1), NEMO, and p65 are reduced as compared with control fibroblasts  that were untreated or stimulated with TNF-α or phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA). β-Actin served as a loading control.
Fif 1F - Western blot analysis of peripheral-blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from Patient 1, which also lack the IKK2 protein.
Homozygous for the same mutation

evidence.detectionMethod: Patient 1 (and patient 2 of family 2) had exome sequencing performed and authors focused on homozygous variants that were not present in control population. parents and sibling had genotype confirmed by Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Normal number of T and B cells. Normal response to PHA but low responses to Pokeweed and Concanavalin A.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1

evidence.dc:description:
Contrary to in healthy controls and heterozygous sibling, anti N- and C- terminal IKKB antibodies failed to detect any full length or truncated IKBKB in patient 1 (and patient 2 of family 2) PBMCs and EBV-transformed B-cell lines. (Fig1E-F). IKBKA was not obviously altered in patient's samples but NEMO was virtually undetectable. 
mRNA levels of IKBKB and NEMO were considerably increased in patients PBMCs (Fig 1G).
Mutation identical by descent.

dc:description:
IKBKB was first reported in relation to an autosomal recessive IKBKB deficiency in 2013 (Pannicke U, et al., 2013, PMID:24369076). Symptoms usually appear in the first few months of life and patients present with a wide range of recurrent infections, failure to thrive and decreased antibody levels. Most patients have normal numbers of T and B cells but these are mostly naïve. All cases reported were homozygous for nonsense mutations. The curation of IKBKB relates to autosomal recessive severe combined immunodeficiency due to IKK2 deficiency with MONDO ID 0014267 includes both case-level and experimental evidence.
The first publication described four cases from four families of Northern Cree ancestry in Canada. Sixteen other cases of Northern Cree ancestry were described by Cuvelier et al. (PMID: 30391351) and all cases with genetic data available confirmed the same nonsense mutation, which suggests a possible founder mutation. Several other cases were found in other populations with different nonsense mutations (PMIDs: 24679846, 32117824, 25216719, 25139357). There are no reports of symptomatic carriers and experimental data showed no effect on heterozygous siblings cells. A maximum score of 12 points for genetic evidence has been reached.
This gene-disease association is also supported by expression, functional alteration and rescue models (PMIDs: 25139357 and 24369076). Absence of protein expression in PBMCs and EBV-transformed B cell lines from patients was found in immunoblot assays, despite mRNA levels remaining high. Also, patient cells transfected with wild-type protein or empty vector and subsequently stimulated showed that cells with WT protein express IKKB protein in the cytosol whereas the ones with empty vector do not. At the same time, Nf-κB expression in the nucleus increased with stimulation when WT gene is present. A different experiment showed normal levels of NF-κB activation by TNF-α were restored in cells from the patient that re-expressed IKKB, even when expression of IKKB was low. A score of 2.5 points for experimental evidence has been reached, increasing the total score to 14.5 points. In summary, IKBKB is definitively associated with autosomal recessive severe combined immunodeficiency due to IKK2 deficiency. In summary, this curation reached a level of "Definitive" as it has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen SCID/CID GCEP on the meeting date May 25, 2023 (SOP Version 9).
